title: AM Projects at Werner-von-Siemens-Centre
content: Focussing on change in production technology

Two new AM research projects, High Temperature Applications (HTA) 2.0 and Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul (MRO) 2.0, have been officially kicked-off in summer 2020 and, besides all odds of the pandemic crisis, are successfully reporting the first milestones already.
The R&D projects address key developments on AM for new designs of gas turbine components and hybrid blade repair.

Aim of the research project: Development of new additive manufacturing processes and components for high-temperature components in large gas turbines, taking into account sustainable product development.

The technology fields of the project include various additive processes and materials, as an extension of the 1st phase, as well as the consideration of the efficient post-processing of AM components, e.g., robot-supported. The developed Design for Additive Manufacturing method will also be supplemented by the other AM processes and integrated into a software environment. In addition, there is a strong focus on sustainable manufacturing, whereby ecological aspects, in terms of life cycle analyses, are considered as early as the design of the components and along the value chain up to their use, thus guiding decisions for future components in the field of energy supply.

Phase II continues to be focused on "Upgrade instead of classic repair" and aims to completely connect the digitized process steps developed in phase I in order to optimize the gas turbine refurbishment process chain and offer our customers tailor-made solutions.

Phase II also focuses on human-machine interaction and the sustainability of our powder and sourcing routes. In the area of additive manufacturing, we are now focusing on the automatic repair of large turbine blades using robot-assisted Wire Arc AM (WAAM).

HTA 2.0 has the focus on new designs, material qualification and L-PBF processes for highly efficient turbine components and is supported by eight partners from R&D and Small and Medium Enterprises from the German Berlin and Brandenburg area.

MRO 2.0 focusses on upgrade instead of classical repair. By combining standardized manufacturing with state-of-the-art technologies such as AM, advanced simulation tools for new materials and digitization (e.g. digital twin), we are able to digitize and automate production and to offer customers tailored solutions with increased value.
The projects are funded by the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF).
